title: Friday, 28th September 2018
bodyHTML:
11:07 am
BE11:07am

Morning. Welcome to Musk Live, FT Alphamusk's daily Musk about the Musk Musk Musk.

Blank canvas good morning everyone
VV75 morning
Manxish Morning peoples

Who can we use as a portrait today?

Alchemy30 Good musk
cheeckychappy @BE - Are you taking the mickey out of somebody?

Airborne Cigar @BE how about Ryan ten Doeschate?
Games Workshop Group PLC (GAW:LSE): Last: 3,775, down 175 (-4.43%), High: 3,845, Low: 3,650, Volume: 638.32k
Soundbuy Morgen
11:11 am

You'll remember back when Kirby was in charge they were stuck in a range of about 200p to 400p for a very long time.

BE11:12am

But can't blame him for taking profit on someone else's work. Anyway, back to the main event.

undefined
wayneJ BE's daily commentary and review of global capitalism.
11:12 am
BE11:13am

SEC doc on Musk's over here: https://www.docume...C-v-Elon-Musk.html

BE11:13am

Comments on the AV post are already alive with takes of various temperatures: https://ftalphavil...-SEC-vs-Elon-Musk/

BE11:15am

So anyway, now that the SEC's throwing around accuasions like "false and misleading" we have to seriously consider the possibility of Tesla without Elon.

Penny morning, sounds like Italian Bank stocks getting a drubbing on Macro news
11:15 am
BE11:16am

As Merrill says .....

BE11:16am

One of the suggested reliefs by SEC is the removal of Musk from the company, which could be a major negative for TSLA stock.

BE11:16am

But would it?

11:16 am
BE11:17am

It'd create a pretty large potential overhang and a considerable uncertainty, but would the company work any worse?

Shinshin @BE don't see why. TSLA problems are about scaling up production vols. THat's not Musk, that's a Ford / GM / BMW person.
Excel Developer @Penny: what macro? political perhaps.
Excel Developer ah CPI
BE11:18am

Let's start with the chances of him reaching a settlement .....

Istrain Think that's a bit unfair on Kirby - he was at Games Workshop for a very long time
BE11:18am

Here's Guggenheim:

11:18 am
BE11:18am

Ours is not a legal opinion, we nevertheless imagine Mr. Musk might hope to settle with the SEC, perhaps on some financial penalty in any way that could keep him at the helm of Tesla. We do not see direct precedents but can harken back to options backdating scandals a dozen years ago that did claim the jobs of several tech executives, and there are instances of SEC cases that ended up removing a CEO. However, we see a big difference in that Mr. Musk does not appear to have attempted to PROFIT from his actions, and his tweets rather look a lot more like an overly cavalier, casual, and potentially reckless mistake than fraudulent action, in our view.

BE11:19am

Which is an argument, though I'm not convinced it's a legally watertight one.

BE11:19am

As in, "his actions (at least in our opinion) do not seem to have had an intention to defraud or drive personal profit, but rather look to us to have been a big mistake (cavalier, casual, and premature for sure, and reckless perhaps, but not fraudulent in our view)."

LK Hyman Morning all. Odds on Unilever losing its proposal to move to 100% Netherlands?
Excel Developer I think UK's authroties are tougher than UK
11:19 am
BE11:20am

I mean, his defence seems largely to be "I chose $420 to amuse my girlf" so, yeah, reckless rather than devious.

BE11:20am

Guggenheim's one of the few buyers out there.

Excel Developer sorry USA tougher than UK's
Provender SEC seem to be more of a danger to TSLA shareholders than Musk so far
BE11:20am

We admit TSLA's list of potential risks now grows even longer with the SEC complaint (after all the company is effectively already attempting to vertically integrate the entire energy + transportation markets; from batteries, silicon, and software to vehicles to retail stores and services), and investors could see it as a hurdle to accessing capital markets for future funding. Our own forecasts are unchanged, however, and rather we look for volume leverage to now start driving Tesla profitability in 2H18E as high-volume Model 3 production enables its economics to flip from cash-burn to cash generation off the big vertically integrated fixed-cost structure the company has been building, putting the company on a path to be SELF funding. Hopeful that the numbers are ultimately what ends up mattering, we maintain our BUY rating and $430 PT.

VV75 DAX taking a nosedive as we speak
11:22 am
BE11:22am

Meanwhile, Cowen (a seller) offers a ten-point range of possibilities on what happens next.

BE11:23am

1) The Board can remove Elon Musk or he can step aside, foregoing his $2.6 billion pay package. This would likely be a big blow to the views of retail shareholders in particular and a handful of institutional investors.
2) Given the financial condition of the company, production problems, and logistics/delivery problems, it is unclear how quickly the Board could bring in a seasoned automotive executive even if they wanted to.
3) In our view, the company still needs to raise $2 billion in 4Q18 to remain a going concern in the Spring of 2019. Given the current equity overhang (production, delivery, legal, etc), we have a hard time envisioning the March 2019 converts converting to equity given the conversion price is ~$360 per share.
4) Given the SEC has now publicly filed its case, we see this as giving a lifeline to civil shareholder cases. What is the exposure to the company relative to Elon personally?
5) We note September 29 is the last trading day of the quarter, which could lead to elevated volumes as long only funds head for the exit. While quantifying the impact of "window dressing" with long only mutual funds not wanting to publicly show quarter end ownership of TSLA shares is impossible, we expect this will occur.

BE11:24am

6) The distraction of Mr. Musk's legal problems may impact 4Q18 performance, a quarter that was guided to be cash flow positive and GAAP profitable. Given the current production run rate and delivery problems, we see Tesla's guidance as ambitious at best.
7) Given Elon Musk's surmounting legal issues, would this impact Tencents' and the Saudi Arabian ownership interest in Tesla shares?
8) In the SEC press conference announcing the lawsuit, they declined to say whether there would be additional charges filed. Investors are concerned that this is just the beginning and there is a "black box" of outcomes from here.
9) Bullish investors are questioning what Mr. Musk's "motive" was in his series of tweets. In our view, it certainly would financially be more convenient for the company to be over the ~$360 March 2019 conversion price for the $920mn debt tranche.
10) Tesla requires positive news flow around the future of the company, innovation in future vehicles and adjacent markets in our view. The question is does this news around Mr. Musk personally impact order rates or more importantly lead to order cancellations. Note that ~40% of the company's cash is currently derived from customer deposits.

Penny @excel, italian budget. BTPs wider
11:25 am
BE11:25am

All of which folds into another idea that was rattling around yesterday -- why doesn't Tesla just turn itself into a licencing company?

Excel Developer @Penny: oh my lord, BTP 10s bust above USTs again https://www.investing.com/rates-bonds/
BE11:25am

Ocado itself, if you like? Stop trying to actually build stuff and just rent out the IP to an actual car company?

Excel Developer @BE: like ARM
BE11:27am

Morgan Stanley kicked that idea around, before the SEC came to kick around Elon and rather stole their thunder.

11:27 am
BE11:27am

GM, Ford,
and FCA face a long term future of connected, electric, and software-enabled mobility, focused primarily on the domestic US market as a public good, not unlike the provision of utilities such as telecom or electricity. Investors are not giving these companies credit for successfully managing this transition, especially as time runs out on the cycle.

Pharma @BE does the US have the equivalent of blanket bans on being a company director? I would think Elon is much more important for the future of Space X than Tesla.
BE11:27am

Meanwhile ......

BE11:27am

On the other side of the country, we have Tesla who still clings to a $50bn valuation and, despite a number of senior management departures, has roughly 40k employees in a highly vertically integrated effort to craft an automated electric transport ecosystem. Tesla is still widely seen by investors, suppliers, and business partners as having a sizable first mover advantage in Auto 2.0. The catch? Tesla has not proven it can sustainably fund its ambitious plans without continued access to outside capital. And for a variety of reasons, the stock market is beginning to seriously question whether the fountain of outside capital will keep flowing.

Excel Developer BTPS 10s yield spike up @12%, whilst Bunds 10s spike down ~14%. Redenomination risk.
11:27 am
BE11:28am

So:

BE11:28am

Necessity is the mother of invention in both the laboratory and in the board
room. We wonder whether a state of mutual necessity could kindle an
exploration of complementary capabilities and deficiencies.

Pharma @Excel, quoting percentage changes for bond prices is very confusing. The idea of bunds at 14% made me double-take.
wayneJ Er? Didn't Elon famously open source Tesla's patents?
Excel Developer @Pharma: ok, as we are close to zero bound, yes, the number can go haywire.
BE11:30am

And there we have it. Replace Musk with Tim Steiner. Close down the tent and rebadge the Jeep Wrangler as a Tesla Model Q. Done. Solved that one. What next?

11:35 am

So. Rome vs Brussels.

wayneJ @Pharma - I should perhaps have said Americans who work on Wall Street and / or invest in Tesla

Here's Natixis to give us some context.

Pharma @wayneJ :-)
BE11:36am

The first market reaction should be negative and we expect the BTP-Bund spread to widen. The position of the market-friendly Finance Minister Giovanni Tria was clearly weakened and, even if his resignation has been denied, political tensions are likely to rise. We see the probability of a downgrade to BBB- before the end of October as high. As a result, Italian bonds could experience periods of sell-off similar to those we have seen in the last months.

Imperial Goldsmith RSA? Is Cevian's holding just a Lord Myner retribution play on Hester; or something more substantive? Appears Job done for Cevian at ThyssenKrupp.
11:36 am
BE11:37am

We didn’t believe that a level below 2% -as pushed by Giovanni Tria - was a real option. In our opinion, this is the “best scenario” we could expect given the government’s willingness to implement, at least partly, their key election proposals. The pension reform and the universal income will be included in the next budget – while the flat tax will only be introduced over time. The crucial question is the credibility of the assumptions underlying the budget draft. So far, we don’t have any additional information regarding the growth projections and the deficit trajectory for 2020-2021. Nevertheless, we suspect that the growth forecasts set in the budget draft is overly optimistic. If so, the government could be forced in the end to renounce the full implementation of some measures, if it wants to respect the budget target.

BE11:37am

Keeping that in mind, we see two main short-terms risks. The first one is the political instability which could materialize in the coming weeks. Giovanni Tria has lost the game and there is a significant risk that he might resign during the following weeks. For the record, the update of the stability program will be presented to Parliament on October 10th and the budget draft on October 20th (after being transferred to the European Commission 5 days before). A high degree of tension in the relations between the government and Brussels will certainly prevail during the whole budgetary process. Then, market participants are also waiting for rating decisions, with S&P reviewing Italy on October 26th and Moody’s before end of October (a precise date still not confirmed). The significant fiscal expansion planned for the coming years is likely to materialize in an Italy’s rating downgrade to BBB-.

FATDAZ @sails well ABN eventually re surfaced as a new dutch bank RBS even asked the biggest client a well known anglo Dutch oil firm to take its non sterling business elsewhere
wayneJ I may be in a minority of one but I think that people underappreciate the brilliance of a common monetary but independent fiscal policy. Suddenly forces countries with weak political / social systems and a history of frequent debt crises to toe the line....surely the real issue is not that it is circa 2.4% but rather that it is not 10% plus which it would be if the current management was unrestrained.

Unfortunately, we do not have to wait for that switch as the budget law is already a negative event that will almost certainly negatively impact financial markets.

Excel Developer @FATDAZ: ok, moving on to theory #2, banks write insurance such as derivatives, if they are lucky the insurance does not pay out, if a bad event materialises then they have to pay out. A bad event means the firm materialisation of a contingent loss.

(Who knows what happens post Brexit; BoE has some 'interesting' views on providing access to the lending window to Italian clearing businesses....)
BE11:49am

Panmure can summarise for us.

Div @chopper bear yeah.....missed the DAX move as a result!!
11:49 am
BE11:49am

RSA has released its Q3 update early to announce a disappointing
performance particularly from the UK and London market that made an underwriting loss of c£70m with a Combined Operating Ratio (COR) of 110%. The reasons appear to be higher weather, large losses and attritional claims. Elsewhere the International performance was good with impressive CORs, but the story of the day will be the UK.
 Y ear to date – Weather losses have been higher in all regions but particularly in Canada and the UK with a Group weather ratio at c4.6% (5 year average 3.2% and Q3 2017: 2.4%)
 E stimates – There is no comment concerning year end expectations but given that the press release was brought forward we assume that consensus 2018F earnings at 47p to 48p are at least 10% too high.
We have cut our 2018F Underlying EPS from 49.4p to 43.1p (-13%) and as a
precaution also pegged back our 2019/20 EPS forecasts to 53.0p (-3%) and 55.5p (-3%) respectively.

wayneJ @Fatdaz - that was part of it but my understanding is that the French King's attitude to debt and borrowing was more blase for centuries
Tom what can Brussel do about Rome anyways, there ain't no sanctions in the history and it doesn't seem likely to be one on the third largest economy in EU
BE11:50am

RSA is a well-run business and non-life insurers will of course be
subject the large weather losses from time to time. Although the share price has come off Summer highs were we viewed them as being priced for perfection, we still think that they are fully valued.
The 2018 PE valuation based on our previous 635p TP was 12.8x. If we apply the same multiple to our revised EPS forecast we achieve a revised TP of 551p/share. However we believe that the one off nature of the impact warrants an amelioration and so have set our new Target price at 593p/share (13.8x 2018F EPS and 11.2x 2019F EPS).
The key question will be the dividend where there is a wide range of estimates based on the assumption that a special dividend will be paid in addition to a normal.

Oh, more Musk.

BE11:53am

We’re downgrading Tesla shares to Sell/High Risk from Neutral/High Risk after Thursday’s SEC action against CEO Elon Musk (seeking a bar on officer/director role less than 2 months after the original go-private tweets), which we think tilts the risk/reward. We frame this development into two potential outcomes: (1) the action leads to Mr. Musk’s exit; and (2) the suit is settled with Mr. Musk staying on.

BE11:53am

That's Citi.

11:53 am
BE11:53am

Price Target — Lower target to $225 on new weights to our terminal value scenarios. We now ascribe a 50%/35%/15% to our Full Bear, Moderate Bull and Full Bull cases. As always, assessing Tesla price targets is inherently a fluid exercise given the potential for extreme outcomes and volatility. We retain a High Risk rating on the stock to reflect this reality.

wayneJ @Pharma - there are some good tables in Rheinhart & Rogoff that I think are definitive on the topic. There is an issue of definition on some of the UK's debt (perpetual war loans) as to whether a default occurred.
11:59 am
BE12:00pm

Despite the poor performance of Spire shares (-40% YTD vs FTSE 100 - 2.3%), Spire shares are not cheap (8.6 x EV/EBITDA 18E). We believe further downgrades to numbers are likely and expect the stock to extend its sector underperformance. We have been cautious for some time on the NHS business, but have clearly underestimated the magnitude of this impact and, going forward, we struggle to see how margins can improve meaningfully from here without a significant acceleration in the top line. We don’t believe this is captured in consensus estimates. Spire also screens worst in our universe based on our assessment of IFRS 16 impacts, which suggests its leverage could reach c.7x in 2019E.

Blank canvas Noonday gun. Gin bottles are uncorked. Thanks for everything this week. Enjoy the weekend BE
Pharma @FATDAZ, as with the Treasury forecasts of recession, predictions of huge job losses will simply be moved forward to some future date.
wayneJ @Fatdaz - I think there are about 10 major banks that count - if the rules mean that they have to move then everyone else is likely to have to move. But also do not confuse a co. moving with the people moving. The issue is how many replacements can they hire locally. Suddenly many London based bankers might find themselves not so irreplaceable....
